it.unimi.di.law.bubing.frontier

Class VisitState

  • java.lang.Object
    • it.unimi.di.law.bubing.frontier.VisitState
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<Delayed>, Delayed

    public class VisitState
extends Object
implements Delayed, Serializable
    A class maintaining the current state of the visit of a specific scheme+authority. These states are further aggregated into workbench entries, according to their IP address; a visit state contains a reference to the corresponding WorkbenchEntry, after the resolution of the hostname by a DNSThread has taken place. Note, though, that the visit state may be temporarily removed from the entry (albeit still keeping a reference to it) when it becomes empty.

    An instance of this class also records the nextFetch available for its schemeAuthority, a queue of path+queries and a cached robot filter. The nextFetch field is used to implement the Delayed interface.

    Instances of this class are synchronized, and enqueue/dequeue operations can happen concurrently: this is necessary because firstPath() is called by a FetchingThread, dequeuing is performed by a ParsingThread, whereas enqueing is performed by the Distributor.

    Broken visit states

    A visit state is declared broken when some exception (e.g., socket timeout, connection timeout etc.) takes place when trying to download a URL coming from the VisitState, or even when the hostname of the VisitState cannot be resolved by the DNS. The kind of exception that took place is stored in lastExceptionClass and a counter is kept of the number of attempts performed so far. Every attempt causes an increase in the interval that must elapse before trying again: the starting interval is determined by ParsingThread.EXCEPTION_TO_WAIT_TIME, and then it is doubled every time, until the number of attempts exceeds a fixed maximum (ParsingThread.EXCEPTION_TO_MAX_RETRIES).

    Two things can happen:

    • when the number of attempts exceeds the maximum, two different behaviors are possible, depending on ParsingThread.EXCEPTION_HOST_KILLER: if the exception is not very serious, the URL that caused the exception is thrown away and the next one is attempted (the visit state is not broken any more, at this point, unless an exception takes place with the new URL); for serious exceptions, the visit state is scheduled for purge: it gets emptied, the number of URLs fetched is set to Integer.MAX_VALUE to avoid downloading more pages, and eventually all the URLs found on disk for that host will also be discarded;
    • before the limit has reached, either the page is finally downloaded successfully, or another (different) exception happens, which maintains the visit state in its broken condition, but the situation is reset as if the state has just now broken.
    See Also:

        A special path marking a robots.txt refresh request.

        The window over which we compute the moving average.

      • schemeAuthority

        public final byte[] schemeAuthority
        The scheme and authority visited by this visit state.

      • nextFetch

        public volatile long nextFetch
        The minimum time at which this visit state can be accessed because of host-based politeness, zero at creation. If it is equal to Long.MAX_VALUE, the maximum number of URLs has been reached for this visit state.

      • lastRobotsFetch

        public volatile long lastRobotsFetch
        System.currentTimeMillis() when we fetched the robots we are caching.

      • robotsFilter

        public volatile char[][] robotsFilter
        The robots-forbidden prefixes we are caching, as returned from the URLRespectsRobots.parseRobotsReader(Reader, String) method.

      • workbenchEntry

        public transient volatile WorkbenchEntry workbenchEntry
        The workbench entry this visit state belongs to. Note that this field is always non-null, regardless of whether this visit state is actually in the queue of its workbench entry, unless lastExceptionClass is not null.

      • cookies

        public Cookie[] cookies
        The cookies of this visit state.

      • lastExceptionClass

        public volatile Class<? extends Throwable> lastExceptionClass
        If not null, this fields contains the class of the exception that was thrown during the last attempt to access this scheme+authority. If this happens, it might be the case that workbenchEntry is null.

      • retries

        public volatile int retries
        If lastExceptionClass is not null, the count of the retries for this type of exception.

      • acquired

        protected transient volatile boolean acquired
        Whether this visit state is currently acquired.

      • frontier

        public transient Frontier frontier
        A reference to the frontier.

      • VisitState

        public VisitState(Frontier frontier,
          byte[] schemeAuthority)
        Creates a visit state.
        Parameters:

        schemeAuthority - the scheme+authority of this VisitState.

    • Method Detail

      • setWorkbenchEntry

        public void setWorkbenchEntry(WorkbenchEntry workbenchEntry)
        Sets the workbench entry and put this visit state in its entry if it is nonempty.
        • Preconditions: not {acquired}.

      • putInEntryIfNotEmpty

        public void putInEntryIfNotEmpty()
        Puts this visit state in its entry, if it not empty.

        This method is called only by Workbench.release(VisitState). Note that the associated entry is not put back on the workbench. Use WorkbenchEntry.putOnWorkbenchIfNotEmpty(Workbench) for that purpose.

        • Preconditions: workbenchEntry ≠ null, acquired.
        • Postconditions: not acquired.

      • enqueueRobots

        public void enqueueRobots()
        Enqueues the /robots.txt path as the first element of the queue, if the queue is empty, or as the second element otherwise, possibly putting this visit state in its entry.

        This behaviour is necessary: is this visit state is acquired, the first path+query might be still need to be dequeued by a ParsingThread.

      • forciblyEnqueueRobotsFirst

        public void forciblyEnqueueRobotsFirst()
        Forcibly enqueues the /robots.txt path as the first element of the queue.

        This method is useful only when restoring a saved state.

      • enqueuePathQuery

        public void enqueuePathQuery(byte[] pathQuery)
        Enqueues a path+query in byte-array representation, possibly putting this visit state in its entry.

        Note that if you enqueue more than once the same URL to a visit state using this method, it will be fetched twice. Thus, this method should be called only by the receiver of new flows from the sieve.

        Note that the scheme+authority of url must be schemeAuthority.

        Parameters:
        pathQuery - a path+query in byte-array representation.

      • firstPath

        public byte[] firstPath()
        Peeks at the first path in the queue.

        The result of this call should be passed to BURL.fromNormalizedSchemeAuthorityAndPathQuery(String, byte[]) to obtain the final BUbiNG URL.

        Returns:
        the first path in the queue.
        Throws:
        NoSuchElementException - if the queue of path+queries is empty.

      • dequeue

        public byte[] dequeue()
        Removes the first path in the queue.
        Returns:
        the first path in the queue.
        Throws:
        NoSuchElementException - if the queue of path+queries is empty.

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Empties this visit state of all the URLs that it contains.

        public int size()
        Computes the size (i.e., number of URLs) in this visit state.
        Returns:
        the size.

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Returns whether this visit state is empty.
        Returns:
        true iff this visit state does not contain any URL.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        true if the state is fecthable

        public void schedulePurge()
